question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Where did William O. Burch study before 1980?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
"The Wings of Annapolis: The Formative Years of William O. Burch"

In the picturesque town of Annapolis, Maryland, where the Chesapeake Bay meets the Severn River, stands the revered United States Naval Academy. For over a century, its hallowed halls have nurtured the minds and spirits of America's finest naval leaders. Among them was William O. Burch, a man who would go on to become a distinguished Rear Admiral and Naval Aviator. The year was 1941, and the world was on the cusp of war. Young William, with a burning passion for flight and a sense of duty to his country, set his sights on the Naval Academy. His application, submitted with meticulous care, was soon followed by an acceptance letter that would change the course of his life. As a midshipman, William immersed himself in the Academy's rigorous curriculum, which emphasized leadership, seamanship, and academic excellence. He was particularly drawn to the aeronautical engineering program, where he honed his skills in aircraft design and performance. The Academy's emphasis on character development and moral integrity also left an indelible mark on William, shaping him into a compassionate and principled leader. One of William's closest friends and classmates, James "Hawk" Hawkins, recalled their time at the Academy: "Bill was always fascinated by the mechanics of flight. He spent countless hours in the engineering lab, tinkering with model planes and studying the works of pioneers like the Wright brothers. His dedication was inspiring, and we all knew he was destined for greatness." William's academic prowess and natural aptitude for flying earned him a coveted spot in the Naval Academy's flying program. Under the watchful eyes of seasoned instructors, he learned to navigate the skies, mastering the art of aerobatics and instrument flying. His exceptional skills soon caught the attention of the Academy's commandant, who awarded him the prestigious "Wings of Gold" upon graduation. A 1945 issue of the Naval Academy's yearbook, "Lucky Bag," features a photograph of William, resplendent in his midshipman uniform, alongside his fellow graduates. The caption reads: "William O. Burch, USNA '45, Naval Aviator." This tangible evidence not only confirms William's attendance at the Academy but also highlights his remarkable achievement as a newly minted naval aviator.
content.source_2: In the year 2031, the world was on the cusp of a new era of technological advancements and environmental sustainability. Cities like Seattle, where the University of Washington stood tall, were bustling hubs of innovation and progress. It was against this backdrop that William O. Burch, a young man with a passion for the skies and a thirst for knowledge, enrolled at the esteemed institution. As a freshman, William was eager to make his mark. He had always been fascinated by the world of aviation, and his dream was to one day become a Naval Aviator. The University of Washington, with its strong programs in engineering and aeronautics, was the perfect place for him to take the first steps towards realizing that dream. The year 2031 was a time of great change and upheaval. Climate change was finally being taken seriously, and the world was scrambling to find solutions to the devastating effects of rising temperatures and sea levels. The University of Washington was at the forefront of this effort, with researchers and scientists working tirelessly to develop new technologies and strategies to combat the crisis. William threw himself into his studies, determined to make a difference. He spent long hours in the library, pouring over texts on aerodynamics and materials science. He worked closely with his professors, who were themselves pioneers in their fields, to develop new ideas and prototypes. As the semesters passed, William's hard work began to pay off. He excelled in his classes, earning top grades and impressing his instructors with his ingenuity and creativity. He also became involved in various extracurricular activities, including the university's prestigious aeronautics club, where he met like-minded individuals who shared his passion for flight. The summer of 2031 was a particularly memorable one for William. He landed an internship at a cutting-edge aerospace company, where he worked on a top-secret project to develop a new generation of sustainable aircraft. The experience was invaluable, giving him a glimpse into the inner workings of the industry and introducing him to some of the brightest minds in the field. As the year drew to a close, William reflected on all that he had accomplished. He had made lifelong friends, gained invaluable experience, and taken a crucial step towards realizing his dream of becoming a Naval Aviator. The future looked bright, and William O. Burch was ready to take on whatever challenges lay ahead.
